timap.about:
About

Kalium is a comprehensive database of potassium channel blockers from scorpion venom (KTx). This database is an open-access resource, and all information presented here is manually curated. Kalium provides easy access to pages of other databases of interest, such as NCBI Taxonomy Browser, UniProt, and PDB.

Database development was supported by the Russian Science Foundation (project no. 14-14-01180).

Please cite: Kalium: a database of potassium channel toxins from scorpion venom. Kuzmenkov A.I., Krylov N.A., Chugunov A.O., Grishin E.V., and Vassilevski A.A. Database (2016); Vol. 2016, article ID baw056; doi: 10.1093/database/baw056.

Developers

Alexey I. Kuzmenkov1, Nikolay A. Krylov2,3, Anton O. Chugunov2, and Alexander A. Vassilevski1

1Molecular Instruments for Neurobiology;

2Biomolecular Modeling, Shemyakin-Ovchinnikov Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, 117997, Russia

3Joint Supercomputer Center, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, 119991, Russia

Experts

  • Prof. Eugene V. Grishin
    Shemyakin-Ovchinnikov Institute of Bioorganic Chemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences
  • Prof. Jan Tytgat
    Toxicology and Pharmacology, University of Leuven
  • Prof. Lourival D. Possani
    Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico 
  • Prof. Ricardo C. Rodríguez de la Vega
    Ecologie, Systématique et Evolution, Université Paris-Sud
  • Prof. Yong-Hua Ji
    Neuropharmacology and Neurotoxicology, Shanghai University
  • Dr. Florence Jungo
    Swiss Institute of Bioinformatics, Centre Medical Universitaire

Contacts

If you have any questions or need support, please do not hesitate to contact us.
timap.help:
Help

All information about potassium channel toxins from scorpion venom is assembled into a table that consists of ten columns:

  1. Selection — permits selection of one or more entries and send them to the Clustal Omega server. If you want to select all entries, click once on the column header. After selection, click the “Clustal” button to show results.
  2. Organism — position of the species according to current classification. One click on the column header opens a menu where you can choose one or more scorpion species. Latin names of the scorpions are linked with the NCBI Taxonomy Browser.
    Use Ctrl/Shift+click for multiple choice. This column is sortable.
  3. Name — toxins are shown grouped in families and subfamilies according to an updated Tytgat-Possani nomenclature. Select family from drop-down menu. Toxin card (see below) opens when clicked on toxin name.
    Use Ctrl/Shift+click for multiple choice. This column is sortable.
  4. Alt. Names — trivial names of toxins. Search option available in the column header.
  5. UniProt ID — UniProt ID is shown, which is linked to corresponding Uniprot page.
  6. Sequence — polypeptide sequence of mature toxin presented in one-letter code. Cysteine residues are marked; different colors indicate the disulfide bond connectivity. “Z” is for N-terminal pyroglutamate. “—NH2” is for C-terminal amidation.
  7. PDB — Shows PDB ID if available, which is linked to corresponding PDB page. Use the filter button to show entries with resolved spatial structure only.
  8. Mass — molecular masses of mature toxins are calculated taking post-translational modifications into account. Italics type means that the full sequence is unknown and valid molecular mass cannot be calculated.
    This column is sortable.
  9. Publication Date — the date when the molecule was first published.
    This column is sortable.
  10. Activity — information about activities on different potassium channels. All tested targets are shown in the list. Toxin card can be opened for detailed information. Use the header to filter toxins according to specific targets.
    Use Ctrl/Shift+click for multiple choice: toxins that have been tested for all the targets.

Toxin card

For every toxin detailed information is summarized in the toxin card, which is accessible by clicking toxin name or activity data.

Please note that all activity data were directly extracted from literature, without additional verification.

Permanent link can be used for citation. The activity data are accumulated in a table containing the following columns:

  1. Target Channel — potassium channels that were used for toxin activity measurements.
  2. Data Type — specifies the type of data reported: dissociation constant (Kd), inhibition constant (Ki), half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC50), or half-maximal effective concentration (EC50).
  3. Method Type — specifies the experimental method applied: radio – radioligand-binding assay; flux – rubidium/thallium efflux assay; patch – electrophysiology using patch-clamp technique; volt – electrophysiology using voltage-clamp technique.
  4. Test System — specifies cell type used for channel expression: insect, Xenopus oocyte, or mammal.
  5. Species — specifies origin of ion channel that was used for measurements. The most common channels belong to fly, rat, mouse, and human.
  6. Value, nM — numeric value of peptide activity (Kd, Ki, IC50, or EC50) presented in nM. Values are shown in the following formats: X — Kd, Ki, IC50, or EC50 value in nM; >X — toxin had no effect up to X value; X/Y — means that toxin at concentration X reduced ion current through the channels by Y percent.
  7. Ref. — reference article.

FAQs

What are ion channels?

Ion channels in general are membrane proteins that serve ion transport through cell membranes by creation of ion-selective or non-selective pores. They are an indispensable feature of life on Earth. Playing leading roles in hormone secretion, cell division and motility, muscle contraction, sense perception, and brain functioning, these proteins are one of the primary targets for drug development.

Further reading:

  1. Hille B. (2001). Ion Channels of Excitable Membranes 3rd ed. Sinauer Associates Inc Sunderland, MA, USA.
  2. Wickenden A., Priest B., Erdemli G. (2012). Ion channel drug discovery: challenges and future directions. Future Med. Chem., 4, 661–79.

What are potassium channels?

Potassium channels are a subset of selective ion channels that conducts K+ ions. Among ion channels, potassium channels form the most populated and diversified superfamily. These channels are found in all living organisms from bacteria to humans. Their fundamental function in the human body is to set the resting potential and shape the action potential in nerves and muscles. Most potassium channels are tetramers of principal α-subunits (heteromeric assemblies are more common), which define their major properties and are often supplemented by auxiliary β-subunits. There are 78 genes encoding α-subunits of potassium channels in the human genome allocated to 5 classes: inwardly rectifying (Kir), two-pore-domain (K2P), voltage-gated (KV), and two classes of calcium-activated potassium channels (KCa), as recommended by the International Union of Basic and Clinical Pharmacology (IUPHAR). There is increasing enthusiasm in the development of medications acting on potassium channels, since these proteins become validated as drug targets.

Further reading:

  1. Hille B. (2001). Ion Channels of Excitable Membranes 3rd ed. Sinauer Associates Inc Sunderland, MA, USA.
  2. González C., Baez-Nieto D., Valencia I., Oyarzún I., Rojas P., Naranjo D., Latorre R. (2012). K+ channels: function-structural overview. Compr. Physiol. 2,2087–149.
  3. Doyle D.A., Morais Cabra J., Pfuetzner R.A., Kuo A., Gulbis J.M., Cohen S.L., Chait B.T., MacKinnon R. (1998). The structure of the potassium channel: molecular basis of K+ conduction and selectivity. Science 280,69–77.
  4. Heinemann S.H., Rettig J., Graack H.R., Pongs O. (1996). Functional characterization of Kv channel beta-subunits from rat brain. J. Physiol. 493 (Pt 3),625–33.
  5. Kubo Y., Adelman J.P., Clapham D.E., Jan L.Y., Karschin A., Kurachi Y., Lazdunski M., Nichols C.G., Seino S., Vandenberg C.A. (2005). International Union of Pharmacology. LIV. Nomenclature and molecular relationships of inwardly rectifying potassium channels. Pharmacol. Rev. 57,509–26.
  6. Goldstein S.A.N., Bayliss D.A., Kim D., Lesage F., Plant L.D., Rajan S. (2005). International Union of Pharmacology. LV. Nomenclature and molecular relationships of two-P potassium channels. Pharmacol. Rev. 57,527–40.
  7. Gutman G.A., Chandy K.G., Grissmer S., Lazdunski M., McKinnon D., Pardo L.A., Robertson G.A., Rudy B., Sanguinetti M.C., Stühmer W., et al. (2005). International Union of Pharmacology. LIII. Nomenclature and molecular relationships of voltage-gated potassium channels. Pharmacol. Rev. 57,473–508.
  8. Wei A.D., Gutman G.A., Aldrich R., Chandy K.G., Grissmer S., Wulff H. (2005). International Union of Pharmacology. LII. Nomenclature and molecular relationships of calcium-activated potassium channels. Pharmacol. Rev. 57,463–72.
  9. Ortiz E., Gurrola G.B., Schwartz E.F., Possani L.D. (2015). Scorpion venom components as potential candidates for drug development. Toxicon 93,125–35.
  10. Wulff H., Castle N.A., Pardo L.A. (2009). Voltage-gated potassium channels as therapeutic targets. Nat. Rev. Drug Discov. 8, 982–1001.

Which chemicals affect potassium channel functioning?

From a chemical standpoint, among potassium channel ligands we note three major classes: metal ions, low-molecular-mass substances, and polypeptides. The diversity of potassium channel ligands may be divided into two large groups, i.e. pore blockers that physically occlude the channel pore, and gating modifiers that affect channel properties otherwise.

Perhaps the most diversified source of potassium channel ligands is scorpion venom: out of approximately 400 polypeptide ligands found in UniProtKB, ~250 are scorpion toxins.

Further reading:

  1. Catterall W.A., Cestèle S., Yarov-Yarovoy V., Yu F.H., Konoki K. and Scheuer T. (2007). Voltage-gated ion channels and gating modifier toxins. Toxicon 49,124–41.
  2. Wulff H., Zhorov B.S. (2008). K+ channel modulators for the treatment of neurological disorders and autoimmune diseases. Chem. Rev. 108,1744–73.
  3. Mouhat S., Andreotti N., Jouirou B., Sabatier J.-M. (2008). Animal toxins acting on voltage-gated potassium channels. Curr. Pharm. Des. 14, 2503–18.

Which scorpion toxins target potassium channels?

All known scorpion toxins affecting potassium channels (KTx) are peptides that act as channel pore blockers. KTx are built of ~20—75 amino acid residues and contain 2–4 disulfide bridges. There are 5 structural folds found in KTx: cysteine-stabilized α/β fold (CSα/β; an overwhelming majority of KTx), CSα/α 2(C-C), CSα/α 3(C-C), Kunitz-type BPTI-like fold, and inhibitor cystine knot (ICK). KTx are often active at nanomolar or even subnanomolar concentrations. Some display marked selectivity with respect to particular subtypes of KV and KCa, but none were reported to be active against Kir or K2P. KTx are utilized to localize potassium channels in biological samples, isolate these proteins, and investigate their pharmacology.

 

The figure shows the structure of charybdotoxin blocking the pore of a KV (PDB ID: 4JTA).

Further reading:

  1. Rodríguez de la Vega R.C., Merino E., Becerril B., Possani L.D. (2003). Novel interactions between K+ channels and scorpion toxins. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 24,222–7.
  2. Mouhat S., Jouirou B., Mosbah A., De Waard M., Sabatier J.-M. (2004). Diversity of folds in animal toxins acting on ion channels. Biochem. J. 378,717–26.
  3. Quintero-Hernández V., Jiménez-Vargas J.M., Gurrola G.B., Valdivia H.H., Possani L.D. (2013). Scorpion venom components that affect ion-channels function. Toxicon, 76,328–42.
  4. Banerjee A., Lee A., Campbell E., Mackinnon R. (2013). Structure of a pore-blocking toxin in complex with a eukaryotic voltage-dependent K+ channel. Elife 2, e00594.

Which nomenclature is used to classify KTx in Kalium?

In 1999, leading scientists in the field proposed a so-called unified nomenclature to address and systematize the growing number of known KTx. With certain modification, this nomenclature lives to date and is supported by the community. Today all KTx are proposed to be grouped into 6 families based on homology, 3D folding pattern, and activity. CSα/β toxins are divided into 3 families: α-KTx (~20-40 residues), β-KTx (~45-75 residues), and γ-KTx (affecting a particular subset of KV, so-called ERG channels). CSα/α toxins are placed in the κ-KTx family, Kunitz toxins are named δ-KTx, and most recently ICK toxins have been proposed to constitute the λ-KTx family. Each family comprises subfamilies that in turn consist of individual KTx grouped by homology.

The nomenclature uses two numbers to identify each toxin, one to specify the subfamily, and the other to specify an individual member. For example, the seminal charybdotoxin is named as α-KTx 1.1 (family α-KTx, subfamily 1, the first member). As new KTx are discovered, subfamily and individual toxin numbers are afforded in a chronological order.

Further reading:

  1. Tytgat J., Chandy K.G., Garcia M.L., Gutman G.A., Martin-Eauclaire M.F., van der Walt J.J., Possani L.D. (1999). A unified nomenclature for short-chain peptides isolated from scorpion venoms: alpha-KTx molecular subfamilies. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 20, 444–7.
  2. Santibáñez-López C.E., Possani L.D. (2015). Overview of the Knottin scorpion toxin-like peptides in scorpion venoms: Insights on their classification and evolution. Toxicon 107, 317–326.
  3. Kuzmenkov A.I., Grishin E.V., Vassilevski A.A. (2015). Diversity of potassium channel ligands: focus on scorpion toxins. Biochemistry (Moscow) 55, 289–350.
